" Full description - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14009475

comment.author: 89563874@N07
comment._content: Yes, I can now see why funnel is missing! It is removed when sailing so that middle sail can swing back and forth.  I have a photo of steam auxiliary barquentine in full sail and the funnel is in horizontal position.  Obvious really.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/sidpickle] Hmmm - I am wondering about this after having a close look at the two photos large size - there are odd differences in the detail of the rigging (number of stays(?) on the hull) and what about the colour of the hull? Did the Witch start off white, turn black, and then back to white again? I'm confused! Wikipedia article (quite good) - en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HMS_Waterwitch_(1892) HMS WATERWITCH in 1894 (black hull) - www.library.uq.edu.au/fryer/hume/web/770.html " " (white hull - same photo as AWM hi-res) - handle.slv.vic.gov.au/10381/28269

comment.author: 89563874@N07
comment._content: Agree about colour. It has bothered me for some time but assumed it was painted for protection of the hull. The funnel being horizontal indicates the yacht came into harbour either under sail or was towed in by a pilot boat of somekind as she could not have been in steam with the funnel down. I previously mentioned the first voyage of the Sunbeam in 1878 and Anna Brassey's book recording events. She also wrote about a later journey to India & Australia that may be of interest and a copy of the book (published after her death) is available at: www.digilibraries.com/html_ebooks/120512/29778/www.digili... This edition on the web link has been beautifully reproduced by someone and includes many of the original drawings. Anna died on the return home to UK and was buried at sea.

comment.author: 89563874@N07
comment._content:
Having gone dizzy counting portholes and their location on several photgraphs of Lancashire Witch, I agree with Beachcomberaustralia's questioning this photo - is it actually of the Lancashire Witch/Waterwitch?  Also his questioning of the rigging is very valid.
In various photographs of the Waterwitch the number of portholes does increase as I assume modifications were carried out for the comfort of the crew in the tropical climates. But this yacht has them in different places.  And the short funnel is strange.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/sidpickle] Ha ha! It's a bit of a puzzle. How's this for a possible solution? - This black ship is the HMS WATERWITCH in 1895 - see the match of rigging and portholes with this hi-res image - handle.slv.vic.gov.au/10381/28269 (undated, could be before coming to Australia) The other photo of the white ship might be the SUNBEAM on the visit to Sydney in July 1887 (pushing the limits on the photographer's operational dates here) See the matching rigging and portholes with this image of the SUNBEAM - handle.slv.vic.gov.au/10381/30542 ?? !! More dizziness about to happen ...

comment.author: 89563874@N07
comment._content:
Yes agree with you about Sunbeam being the white yacht in the other photo.  She does match a photo I have of the her. Well done.  
I'll have a few more looks at the photo above and get back to you.
I left a comment on the other page for the white yacht as well.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/sidpickle] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Thanks folks, some new images up on the photostream of possible SUNBEAMs. Beachcomber - William Frederick Hall (the senior Hall) had a photographic studio set up by 1890, but he arrived in Australia about 1874 so I suppose he had time to be developing as a photographer when SUNBEAM arrived with the Brassey's. WF Hall's patent application regarding photographic equipment (in the NAA) dates to 1888 so it would be safe to say he was involved in photography before his studio arrives on the record. Another detail to throw into the ring...
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] That is good to know about Mr Hall. Thanks. I am fairly sure this is HMS Waterwitch in 1895 because of the building work seen on the Colonial Secretary's Office - an extra floor with mansard roof and windows (seen here) and the dome on top to come.

comment.author: 89563874@N07
comment._content:
I still have doubts that it is Waterwitch.  Simple example is the bowsprit and forestays.  They do not match other photos of Lancashire Witch/Waterwitch.  Mast fittings differ and using the people as a guide she just seems a bigger vessel.  
Reference funnel - (assuming the short stub behind the middle mast is the funnel) such a short one could indicate it was a donkey boiler for fast steaming when in port but its diameter is BIG so it must be main boiler.  The tall funnels were required to induce draught in marine application so if this is a short funnel could it indicate perhaps verical boiler?  I'm no expert so perhaps there is a steam person who could be consulted?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/sidpickle] You are quite right to have your doubts, and prompt me to have another look - I went a-Troving, searching for "three-masted schooner farm cove" in the 1890s ... ... ... B-I-N-G-O-! She is the steam yacht ST. GEORGE Royal Yacht Squadron (R.Y.S.) which arrived in Sydney in April 1892 on a world cruise, and moored in in Farm Cove. Primary proof - an article in the Australian Town and Country Journal of 14/5/1892, p.27, with two illustrations, one of which is [drumroll ... ...] this photo with the credit line - "FROM A PHOTOGRAPH BY MR. HALL, PHILLIP-STREET" - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/71238003 - It's a wonderful "chatty" [sic] read!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The ST. GEORGE arrived on Sunday 17/4/1892 as reported the next day in the SMH - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13852629 Like the SUNBEAM there was a book of the voyage "The Cruise of the "St. George" R.Y.S., to see the World, 1891-92" (published 1893) - ebooks archive.org/details/cihm_14297 A zoomable illustration from the ebook - archive.org/stream/cihm_14297#page/n20/mode/1up , which shows the stumpy funnel (imho) [PHEW !]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The ebook description of Sydney begins on p.197 - archive.org/stream/cihm_14297#page/n221/mode/1up

comment.author: 89563874@N07
comment._content:
Registered with RYS 1891 - E J Wythes - looks like 850 tons on the RYS register although newspaper says 1000, so no matter which, she is bigger than either Sunbeam or Waterwitch.
Another "well done" coming your way BeachcomberAustralia. 
I may be able to look up the Lloyds Yacht Registers for her details later this month at Southampton Library maritime section.  They have a good set dating back to before 1880 (with a few gaps).  If so I'll post the details.
Another caption change required if the Maritime Museum concur?

comment._content: Counting yacht portholes in the month of May Dizzy feelings be(water)witched the day Along came the 'comber With wisdom of Homer - "She is the ST. GEORGE in April (not May)."

comment.author: 89563874@N07
comment._content:
Lloyds yacht register for details in 1892: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/sidpickle/8937048985/].  St George did service during first world war as Oriflamme and then Wallington base ship (J J Colledge "Ships of the Royal Navy" Volume II).She appears to have become a training ship with Devitt and Moore (as did Sunbeam) in 1920 [http://www.flickr.com/photos/sidpickle/8940027788/]
Research Expeditions in 1924 [http://www.flickr.com/photos/sidpickle/8940022612/] 
and last record of her I can find is 1929 with May & Butcher Limited who were a timber merchant and possibly dismantled her.[http://www.flickr.com/photos/sidpickle/8940017574/]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/sidpickle] You are hearby awarded the Flickr Medal for Services Over and Beyond The Call of Duty. The last photo is of particular interest to me as it shows another St GEORGE yacht, 5132, built 1927, owner Col E.T. Peel. He was a friend of my maternal grandfather, and they used to go on fishing trips in the Mediterranean and off Scarborough (for tunny) in the 1930s. I had a vague idea / hope that they might have been the same ship, but no. Great stuff!

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Agreed BC [http://www.flickr.com/photos/sidpickle] This stuff is wonderful, for ST GEORGE and SUNBEAM, to know definitively their fates. I am attaching your records to our catalogue entries for the images of these vessels, rather than a wiring diagram I think they'll look pretty full & good!
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 89563874@N07
comment._content: One of those tenuous links: St George was built in 1890 by Ramage & Ferguson from a design by W C Storey. The following year the same yard and same designer built Ladye Mabel for Lord Ashbuton. A year later the yacht was purchased by George Alexander Baird as a present for Lillie Langtry (following a slight disturbance in a Paris hotel room) and renamed White Ladye. On the web it is possible to find references that the White Ladye became HMS Waterwitch and this has been disproven as a myth following research and a documented audit trail of Lloyd's registers for both yachts. Although not linked to the yacht but of Australian interest: Langtry was told of an Australian race horse called Merman that was a good prospect and had him shipped over to the UK. The horse proved to be one of the great stayers of his age and won some impressive races www.brisbaneracing.com.au/article.php?current_article=4707 [http://www.flickr.com/photos/sidpickle/8987145335/] White Ladye was sold to the inventor of Bovril -John Lawson Johnston - who died on board, then to a ship builder William C Gray www.gracesguide.co.uk/William_Gray_and_Co and eventually became French Trawler La Champagne out of Fecamp. float-trawlers.lancashire.gov.uk/index.php?a=forward&...

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/sidpickle] Oh dear! 'White Ladye' does not have the most pleasant origins re Langtry & Baird... I love how one photo can lead to the airing of so many stories, thanks for sharing your research :)
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 72585839@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/sidpickle] 

David Blair - the original second officer of the Titanic who was bumped off during the officer reshuffle- was in command of the St. George during that 1924 expedition. I have a grainy image of the St. George just prior to setting sail on that particular expedition - she had been painted white by then, however.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/a_look_into_the_past] Interesting connection to TITANIC - thanks for pointing it out. The stories of these vessels just get more and more fascinating.
